segment.source: Configure Windows Defender in Windows 10 (Windows 10)
segment.target: Configure Windows Defender in Windows 10 (Windows 10)

segment.source: IT professionals can configure definition updates and cloud-based protection in Windows Defender in Windows 10 through Microsoft Active Directory and Windows Server Update Services (WSUS).
segment.target: IT professionals can configure definition updates and cloud-based protection in Windows Defender in Windows 10 through Microsoft Active Directory and Windows Server Update Services (WSUS).

segment.source: Configure Windows Defender in Windows 10
segment.target: Configure Windows Defender in Windows 10

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: IT professionals can configure definition updates and cloud-based protection in Windows Defender in Windows 10 through Microsoft Active Directory and Windows Server Update Services (WSUS).
segment.target: IT professionals can configure definition updates and cloud-based protection in Windows Defender in Windows 10 through Microsoft Active Directory and Windows Server Update Services (WSUS).

segment.source: Configure definition updates
segment.target: Configure definition updates

segment.source: It is important to update definitions regularly to ensure that your endpoints are protected.
segment.target: It is important to update definitions regularly to ensure that your endpoints are protected.

segment.source: Definition updates can be configured to suit the requirements of your organization.
segment.target: Definition updates can be configured to suit the requirements of your organization.

segment.source: Windows Defender supports the same updating options (such as using multiple definition sources) as other Microsoft endpoint protection products; for more information, see Configuring Definition Updates.
segment.target: Windows Defender supports the same updating options (such as using multiple definition sources) as other Microsoft endpoint protection products; for more information, see Configuring Definition Updates.

segment.source: When you configure multiple definition sources in Windows Defender, you can configure the fallback order using the following values through Group Policy settings:
segment.target: When you configure multiple definition sources in Windows Defender, you can configure the fallback order using the following values through Group Policy settings:

segment.source: InternalDefinitionUpdateServer - WSUS
segment.target: InternalDefinitionUpdateServer - WSUS

segment.source: MicrosoftUpdateServer - Microsoft Update
segment.target: MicrosoftUpdateServer - Microsoft Update

segment.source: MMPC - Microsoft Malware Protection Center definitions page
segment.target: MMPC - Microsoft Malware Protection Center definitions page

segment.source: FileShares - file share
segment.target: FileShares - file share

segment.source: Read about deploying administrative template files for Windows Defender in the article Description of the Windows Defender Group Policy administrative template settings.
segment.target: Read about deploying administrative template files for Windows Defender in the article Description of the Windows Defender Group Policy administrative template settings.

segment.source: You can also manage your Windows Defender update configuration settings through System Center Configuration Manager.
segment.target: You can also manage your Windows Defender update configuration settings through System Center Configuration Manager.

segment.source: See How to Configure Definition Updates for Endpoint Protection in Configuration Manager for details.
segment.target: See How to Configure Definition Updates for Endpoint Protection in Configuration Manager for details.

segment.source: Definition update logic
segment.target: Definition update logic

segment.source: You can update Windows Defender definitions in four ways depending on your business requirements:
segment.target: You can update Windows Defender definitions in four ways depending on your business requirements:

segment.source: WSUS, the managed server.
segment.target: WSUS, the managed server.

segment.source: You can manage the distribution of updates that are released through Microsoft Update to computers in your enterprise environment; read more on the Windows Server Update Services website.
segment.target: You can manage the distribution of updates that are released through Microsoft Update to computers in your enterprise environment; read more on the Windows Server Update Services website.

segment.source: Microsoft Update, the unmanaged server.
segment.target: Microsoft Update, the unmanaged server.

segment.source: You can use this method to get regular updates from Microsoft Update.
segment.target: You can use this method to get regular updates from Microsoft Update.

segment.source: The Microsoft Malware Protection Center definitions page, as an alternate download location.
segment.target: The Microsoft Malware Protection Center definitions page, as an alternate download location.

segment.source: You can use this method if you want to download the latest definitions.
segment.target: You can use this method if you want to download the latest definitions.

segment.source: File share, where the definition package is downloaded.
segment.target: File share, where the definition package is downloaded.

segment.source: You can retrieve definition updates from a file share.
segment.target: You can retrieve definition updates from a file share.

segment.source: The file share must be provisioned on a regular basis with the update files.
segment.target: The file share must be provisioned on a regular basis with the update files.

segment.source: Update Windows Defender definitions through Active Directory and WSUS
segment.target: Update Windows Defender definitions through Active Directory and WSUS

segment.source: This section details how to update Windows Defender definitions for Windows 10 endpoints through Active Directory and WSUS.
segment.target: This section details how to update Windows Defender definitions for Windows 10 endpoints through Active Directory and WSUS.

segment.source: Method
segment.target: Method

segment.source: Instructions
segment.target: Instructions

segment.source: WSUS
segment.target: WSUS

segment.source: See Software Updates and Windows Server Update Services Definition Updates in the Configuring Definition Updates topic that also applies to Windows Defender.
segment.target: See Software Updates and Windows Server Update Services Definition Updates in the Configuring Definition Updates topic that also applies to Windows Defender.

segment.source: Microsoft Update
segment.target: Microsoft Update

segment.source: Set the following fallback order Group Policy to enable Microsoft Update:
segment.target: Set the following fallback order Group Policy to enable Microsoft Update:

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Editor.
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Editor.

segment.source: In the Local Computer Policy tree, expand Computer Configuration, then Administrative Templates, then Windows Components, then Windows Defender.
segment.target: In the Local Computer Policy tree, expand Computer Configuration, then Administrative Templates, then Windows Components, then Windows Defender.

segment.source: Click on Signature Updates.
segment.target: Click on Signature Updates.

segment.source: Double-click on Define the order of sources for downloading definition updates.
segment.target: Double-click on Define the order of sources for downloading definition updates.

segment.source: This will open the Define the order of sources for downloading definition updates window.
segment.target: This will open the Define the order of sources for downloading definition updates window.

segment.source: Click Enable.
segment.target: Click Enable.

segment.source: In the Options pane, define the following Group Policy to enable Microsoft Update:
segment.target: In the Options pane, define the following Group Policy to enable Microsoft Update:

segment.source: {MicrosoftUpdateServer}
segment.target: {MicrosoftUpdateServer}

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: The window will close automatically.
segment.target: The window will close automatically.

segment.source: Microsoft Malware Protection Center definitions page
segment.target: Microsoft Malware Protection Center definitions page

segment.source: Set the following fallback order Group Policy to enable Windows Defender to download updated signatures:
segment.target: Set the following fallback order Group Policy to enable Windows Defender to download updated signatures:

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Editor.
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Editor.

segment.source: In the Local Computer Policy tree, expand Computer Configuration, then Administrative Templates, then Windows Components, then Windows Defender.
segment.target: In the Local Computer Policy tree, expand Computer Configuration, then Administrative Templates, then Windows Components, then Windows Defender.

segment.source: Click on Signature Updates.
segment.target: Click on Signature Updates.

segment.source: Double-click on Define the order of sources for downloading definition updates.
segment.target: Double-click on Define the order of sources for downloading definition updates.

segment.source: This will open the Define the order of sources for downloading definition updates window.
segment.target: This will open the Define the order of sources for downloading definition updates window.

segment.source: Click Enable.
segment.target: Click Enable.

segment.source: In the Options pane, define the following Group Policy to enable Windows Defender to download updated signatures:
segment.target: In the Options pane, define the following Group Policy to enable Windows Defender to download updated signatures:

segment.source: {MMPC}
segment.target: {MMPC}

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: The window will close automatically.
segment.target: The window will close automatically.

segment.source: File share
segment.target: File share

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Editor.
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Editor.

segment.source: In the Local Computer Policy tree, expand Computer Configuration, then Administrative Templates, then Windows Components, then Windows Defender.
segment.target: In the Local Computer Policy tree, expand Computer Configuration, then Administrative Templates, then Windows Components, then Windows Defender.

segment.source: Click on Signature Updates.
segment.target: Click on Signature Updates.

segment.source: Double-click on Define the order of sources for downloading definition updates.
segment.target: Double-click on Define the order of sources for downloading definition updates.

segment.source: This will open the Define the order of sources for downloading definition updates window:
segment.target: This will open the Define the order of sources for downloading definition updates window:

segment.source: Click Enable.
segment.target: Click Enable.

segment.source: In the Options pane, define the following Group Policy to enable Windows Defender to download updated signatures:
segment.target: In the Options pane, define the following Group Policy to enable Windows Defender to download updated signatures:

segment.source: {FileShares}
segment.target: {FileShares}

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: The window will close automatically.
segment.target: The window will close automatically.

segment.source: Double-click on Define file shares for downloading definition updates.
segment.target: Double-click on Define file shares for downloading definition updates.

segment.source: This will open the Define file shares for downloading definition updates window.
segment.target: This will open the Define file shares for downloading definition updates window.

segment.source: Click Enable.
segment.target: Click Enable.

segment.source: In the Options pane, define the following Group Policy to specify the Universal Naming Convention (UNC) share source:
segment.target: In the Options pane, define the following Group Policy to specify the Universal Naming Convention (UNC) share source:

segment.source: {unc1unc2} where you define [unc] as the UNC shares.
segment.target: {unc1unc2} where you define [unc] as the UNC shares.

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: The window will close automatically.
segment.target: The window will close automatically.

segment.source: Manage cloud-based protection
segment.target: Manage cloud-based protection

segment.source: Windows Defender offers improved cloud-based protection and threat intelligence for endpoint protection clients using the Microsoft Active Protection Service.
segment.target: Windows Defender offers improved cloud-based protection and threat intelligence for endpoint protection clients using the Microsoft Active Protection Service.

segment.source: Read more about the Microsoft Active Protection Service community in Join the Microsoft Active Protection Service community.
segment.target: Read more about the Microsoft Active Protection Service community in Join the Microsoft Active Protection Service community.

segment.source: You can enable or disable the Microsoft Active Protection Service using Group Policy settings and administrative template files.
segment.target: You can enable or disable the Microsoft Active Protection Service using Group Policy settings and administrative template files.

segment.source: More information on deploying administrative template files for Windows Defender is available in the article Description of the Windows Defender Group Policy administrative template settings.
segment.target: More information on deploying administrative template files for Windows Defender is available in the article Description of the Windows Defender Group Policy administrative template settings.

segment.source: The Microsoft Active Protection Service can be configured with the following Group Policy settings:
segment.target: The Microsoft Active Protection Service can be configured with the following Group Policy settings:

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Editor.
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Editor.

segment.source: In the Local Computer Policy tree, expand Computer Configuration, then Administrative Templates, then Windows Components, then Windows Defender.
segment.target: In the Local Computer Policy tree, expand Computer Configuration, then Administrative Templates, then Windows Components, then Windows Defender.

segment.source: Click on MAPS.
segment.target: Click on MAPS.

segment.source: Double-click on Join Microsoft MAPS.
segment.target: Double-click on Join Microsoft MAPS.

segment.source: Select your configuration option from the Join Microsoft MAPS list.
segment.target: Select your configuration option from the Join Microsoft MAPS list.

segment.source: Note: Any settings modified on an endpoint will be overridden by the administrator's policy setting.
segment.target: Note: Any settings modified on an endpoint will be overridden by the administrator's policy setting.

segment.source: Use the Windowsdefender.adm Group Policy template file to control the policy settings for Windows Defender in Windows 10:
segment.target: Use the Windowsdefender.adm Group Policy template file to control the policy settings for Windows Defender in Windows 10:

segment.source: Policy setting: Configure Microsoft SpyNet Reporting
segment.target: Policy setting: Configure Microsoft SpyNet Reporting

segment.source: Registry key name: HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREPoliciesMicrosoftWindows DefenderSpyNetSpyNetReporting
segment.target: Registry key name: HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREPoliciesMicrosoftWindows DefenderSpyNetSpyNetReporting

segment.source: Policy description: Adjusts membership in Microsoft Active Protection Service
segment.target: Policy description: Adjusts membership in Microsoft Active Protection Service

segment.source: You can also configure preferences using the following PowerShell parameters:
segment.target: You can also configure preferences using the following PowerShell parameters:

segment.source: Turn Microsoft Active Protection Service off: Set-MpPreference -MAPSReporting 0
segment.target: Turn Microsoft Active Protection Service off: Set-MpPreference -MAPSReporting 0

segment.source: Turn Microsoft Active Protection Service on: Set-MpPreference -MAPSReporting 2
segment.target: Turn Microsoft Active Protection Service on: Set-MpPreference -MAPSReporting 2

segment.source: Read more about this in:
segment.target: Read more about this in:

segment.source: Scripting with Windows PowerShell
segment.target: Scripting with Windows PowerShell

segment.source: Defender Cmdlets
segment.target: Defender Cmdlets

segment.source: Note: Any information that Windows Defender collects is encrypted in transit to our servers, and then stored in secure facilities.
segment.target: Note: Any information that Windows Defender collects is encrypted in transit to our servers, and then stored in secure facilities.

segment.source: Microsoft takes several steps to avoid collecting any information that directly identifies you, such as your name, email address, or account ID.
segment.target: Microsoft takes several steps to avoid collecting any information that directly identifies you, such as your name, email address, or account ID.

segment.source: Read more about how to manage your privacy settings in Setting your preferences for Windows 10 services.
segment.target: Read more about how to manage your privacy settings in Setting your preferences for Windows 10 services.

segment.source: Opt-in to Microsoft Update
segment.target: Opt-in to Microsoft Update

segment.source: You can use Microsoft Update to keep definitions on mobile computers running Windows Defender in Windows 10 up to date when they are not connected to the corporate network.
segment.target: You can use Microsoft Update to keep definitions on mobile computers running Windows Defender in Windows 10 up to date when they are not connected to the corporate network.

segment.source: If the mobile computer doesn't have a Windows Server Update Service (WSUS) connection, the signatures will still come from Microsoft Update.
segment.target: If the mobile computer doesn't have a Windows Server Update Service (WSUS) connection, the signatures will still come from Microsoft Update.

segment.source: This means that signatures can be pushed down (via Microsoft Update) even if WSUS overrides Windows Update.
segment.target: This means that signatures can be pushed down (via Microsoft Update) even if WSUS overrides Windows Update.

segment.source: You need to opt-in to Microsoft Update on the mobile computer before it can retrieve the definition updates from Microsoft Update.
segment.target: You need to opt-in to Microsoft Update on the mobile computer before it can retrieve the definition updates from Microsoft Update.

segment.source: There are two ways you can opt-in to Microsoft Update in Windows Defender for Windows 10:
segment.target: There are two ways you can opt-in to Microsoft Update in Windows Defender for Windows 10:

segment.source: Use a VBScript to create a script, then run it on each computer in your network.
segment.target: Use a VBScript to create a script, then run it on each computer in your network.

segment.source: Manually opt-in every computer on your network through the Settings menu.
segment.target: Manually opt-in every computer on your network through the Settings menu.

segment.source: You can create a VBScript and run it on each computer on your network; this is an efficient way to opt-in to Microsoft Update.
segment.target: You can create a VBScript and run it on each computer on your network; this is an efficient way to opt-in to Microsoft Update.

segment.source: Use a VBScript to opt in to Microsoft Update
segment.target: Use a VBScript to opt in to Microsoft Update

segment.source: Use the instructions in the MSDN article Opt-In to Microsoft Update to create the VBScript.
segment.target: Use the instructions in the MSDN article Opt-In to Microsoft Update to create the VBScript.

segment.source: Run the VBScript you created on each computer in your network.
segment.target: Run the VBScript you created on each computer in your network.

segment.source: You can manually opt-in each individual computer on your network to receive Microsoft Update.
segment.target: You can manually opt-in each individual computer on your network to receive Microsoft Update.

segment.source: Manually opt-in to Microsoft Update
segment.target: Manually opt-in to Microsoft Update

segment.source: Open Windows Update in Update & security settings on the computer you want to opt-in.
segment.target: Open Windows Update in Update & security settings on the computer you want to opt-in.

segment.source: Click Advanced options.
segment.target: Click Advanced options.

segment.source: Select the checkbox for Give me updates for other Microsoft products when I update Windows.
segment.target: Select the checkbox for Give me updates for other Microsoft products when I update Windows.

segment.source: Schedule updates for Microsoft Update
segment.target: Schedule updates for Microsoft Update

segment.source: Opting-in to Microsoft Update means that your system administrator can schedule updates to your mobile computer, so that it keeps up-to-date with the latest software versions and security definitions, even when you’re on the road.
segment.target: Opting-in to Microsoft Update means that your system administrator can schedule updates to your mobile computer, so that it keeps up-to-date with the latest software versions and security definitions, even when you’re on the road.

segment.source: For more information on scheduling updates, see Configure definition updates.
segment.target: For more information on scheduling updates, see Configure definition updates.
